reviewText: Are you one of those people that watches an advertisement on TV of a product with a name similar to a known product and feel the urge to buy it? Do you always scratch mosquito bites? Do you pick at open wounds? Do you like to run with scissors? Do you like to poke yourself in the eye with a stick? Do you often shoot yourself in the foot? This DVD is for you. It is guaranteed to make have dreams of "Galaxy of Terror" the real legit movie dancing in your head along with other good SciFi that isn't in the mainstream. Then once you open it and play the movies that are in it you will realize either, you have been a fool to be so naive, or that some companies and individuals get away with ripping people off here when they shouldn't. The only terror here is that Amazon can't possibly check out every item that is sold on their site. Therefore once in awhile total trash like this is going to slip into what is for sale. But once pointed out by reviewers like us at least we can save some from the pain of actually watching this, and better yet the pain of having to return it. I think these companies or individuals that try to market rip-offs should be made to suffer by forcing them to watch these type so bad they aren't even funny movies for days. Then perhaps they would see the error of their ways.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This sorry collection of lame movies gathered together is just another reason not to pre-order a movie,based on just the title.One out of four movies is still, in my book, just not the right reason, to sell this crap collection.From now on,I'm not buying anything without a complete review!! I really would rate this collection with a MINUS 3!!!
summary: NOT the one your wishing for!!!

reviewText: i think i'm not alone in believeing that this bottom of the barrel collection of sci-fi movies(bad sci-fi movies)is the pits.the movies are almost as bad as the transfers of them are. not worth the price ever!!!!!!
summary: this "collection" is just another rip-off with very poor transfers

reviewText: Luckily I had the good sense to rent this movie first.  I wasn't even worth the rental price from Netflix.  I don't even think I watched more than the first move.  I started the other 3, but they seemed to be even worse then the first was.  Don't just stay from this sorry collection.  Run away as fast as possible.

reviewText: "Galaxy of Terror" is a set of four short extremely low-budget movies by the Polonia brothers and their associates. I have seen plenty of cheap independent films before, but these are in a class by themselves. These films are so cheap that there isn't even an attempt at disguising that most of the monsters are hand puppets of the type used to entertain gullible two year olds, that a spaceship is being flown by something that looks suspiciously like an Atari joystick on a table, that astronaut uniforms consists of chukkas, jeans and a pullover, and that the ultra-brilliant spacecraft computer "KAL" (no, not "HAL," just to be clear) appears to be a slide projector, as best I can determine.As for the films themselves, they are all around 70 minutes long, so the suffering, while bitter, is brief (although it may not feel that way.) They all kind of run together in my mind as they all have very similar leitmotifs, with "The Weapon" being a bit different than the rest conceptually. I didn't watch them in any particular order, I just popped a disc in the DVD player on whatever side was up and pressed play. I started, it turns out, with "Preylien: Alien Predators," which was unfortunate as it was one of the better films of the bunch ("better" is a highly relative term.) I will tell you up front that it helps to read the DVD case for all of these films before watching them, as there is little narrative sensibility in any of them, and it helps you know what is supposedly going on."Preylien" was the most sensible of the four, and it reminded me of a demented cross between "Robot Monster" (ridiculous part-fur, part-vest creatures,) and "Alien." Essentially it involves a spaceship crashing on Earth, releasing some dreadful aliens to terrorize the human race, and the human's attempts to live. The effects are unbelievable and hilarious (please especially enjoy the terrifying "star-spider" and the utterly ridiculous eyeball creature from the DVD cover,) the acting, script, and direction is extremely poor, and the sets are pretty much nonexistent. I was especially fond of the access to the spacecraft which was obtained by a normal doorway with a couple of old shower doors used to represent the futuristic portal to the vessel. This turned out to be my favorite of the bunch. I had no idea what was waiting for me when I turned the disc over.When I turned the disc over the next night, I found the reprehensible and inexcusably bad duality of a film called "The Dinosaur Chronicles." I believe that this film is the worst of the four, and illustrates everything that is wrong with these movies (albeit with hilarious results.) This film has the worst special effects, which largely consist of dinosaur hand puppets (watch for the arms sticking out the back.) This apparently started out as two separate movies that the Polonia brothers didn't know what to do with, but which were individually too short to be a feature. That's my guess, anyway, because the movie starts with some wholly unlikable louts on a cruise. Their boat sinks leaving them to wash ashore on a mysterious island (near Cuba) that is occupied by dinosaurs. The acting makes for a painful viewing experience, although I have to say that the effects made me laugh out loud often. Before you know it, we're off to the future where a lunatic named Caesar has destroyed the Earth with atomic weapons, and has released dinosaurs to do his bidding. In other words, in the second half hand puppets chase people around deserted corridors instead of a forest. Neither half makes a great deal of sense on their own, and juxtaposed with each other the experience is truly jarring.Summoning up all my bravery, I inserted the second disc, and up came "Blood Red Planet." This one is a real mess that badly mixes stock footage of NASA spacecraft with some of the worst sets, and definitely the worst acting of the four. There are some amusing newscasts cut in to provide some kind of narrative continuity, a wholly unbelievable cast complete with a captain and a doctor who are at loggerheads about the intentions of the (obviously evil) aliens. The dialogue is beyond campy, and the effects are just the worst (I was especially fond of the ships computer, "KAL," which was represented by what appears to be a slide projector with "KAL" decaled on the side) and the costumes are beyond hilarious. The uniform of the day for exploring a hostile planet is jeans, a mock-turtle pullover, a dust mask like you would wear in a wood shop, and safety goggles (or a close facsimile thereof.) If you don't laugh at the space exploration gear, you surely won't be able to resist laughing at the super-weapon mega-explosive they use, which looks suspiciously like a home smoke detector (this is a trend in the set, by the way.) "Blood Red Planet" has pretentious aspirations and inspiration from decades of sci-fi movies (some good and some bad.) I liken it to the worst parts of "Alien" (where the doctor sympathizes and helps the alien force) with the aesthetic of "Zontar: The Thing From Venus" (same reason,) and the budget of "Plan 9 From Outer Space" if Ed Wood had one-tenth the funding he actually had. Bad? Yes. Hilarious? Yes. Entertaining? If you like cinematic cheese, undoubtedly.Finally I watched "The Weapon" which was kind of like "Waterworld" in reverse, where the government of "Feldspar IV" controls every drop of water. There are multiple plot threads going at once, but suffice it to say that there are forces at work to use an ancient weapon (that turns out to be a drill) to obtain water for all. There are some humorous effects (I especially like the rocket sleds) and some terrible acting, all wrapped in a quite confusing premise, served with a huge amount of unfathomable, pretentious, and ridiculous dialogue (e.g. "Holy mother of Feldspar!" and "I should dehydrate you to kingdom come!") This one wasn't directed by the Polonia brothers, and while it is a terrible and confusing movie, it is stylistically the most refined of the set, although it doesn't seemingly have any more clarity of purpose. Please watch all the way to the end, otherwise you will miss the ceremony of the phosphorescent space loogie. (Trust me on this one.)"Galaxy of Terror" has absolutely nothing to recommend it if you are looking for well-crafted, tension-filled, quality cinema. If, on the other hand, you are looking for dumpster-quality cheese-filled movies full on unintentional laughs and you have an extremely high tolerance for cinematic pain, this is a bargain of unimaginable value. As cinematic achievements any of these films deserves to be rated far below zero, but I can't resist a three star rating simply for the laughable badness, sincere ineptness, and unadulterated cheesiness of the set.
summary: A Truly Astonishing Body Of Work From John And Mark Polonia
